content: w d c raptor irector s ut deleted scenes & special features sometimes you have to cut in order to make something fit such was the case with wraptor so i offer to you here a variety of additional resources and geeknotes to explore contents  frequently asked questions  troubleshooting the fit  charts  variations  knitting off the grid frequently asked questions why do i have to make a gauge swatch because with wraptor if your gauge doesn t match the sock probably won t fit with traditional socks you can fudge but with wraptor you can t matching stitch gauge 8 st/in is critical when you cast on you re setting the entire length of your leg and foot all at once this cannot be course-corrected later if you realize your sock is going to be too big or too small the pattern and all associated resources make the assumption that you are working to 8 st/inch * matching row gauge 11 25 row/inch is important but not critical the number of row you work determines the width of your sock but if your row gauge is a little off it s possible to compensate by working more or fewer row what s a checkpoint why should i care about these checkpoints are your means of verifying that your sock is going to fit since you can t try on wraptor as you go you can t assess the fit by how it feels you have to trust the numbers at checkpoint 1 you have an opportunity to evaluate whether your row gauge is on or off target any margin for error here will be multiplied by 3 by the time you get to the end of the sock so if you re off target here plan on making some adjustments during the next stage * if you re willing to jailbreak the pattern and work to your own gauge you can do this but this is a non-trivial adjustment to the process recommended for adventurous knitters only refer to knitting off the grid for tips on working to your own gauge checkpoint 2 is your opportunity to make whatever adjustments you need if your row gauge is off target this is a key point in the process because once you pass checkpoint 2 you can t adjust your fabric width if you discover later that your sock doesn t fit you ll have to rip back to this point and re-adjust at checkpoint 3 you ll find out whether or not your sock will fit if your fabric doesn t match your target width at checkpoint 3 do not proceed to stage 4 rip back to checkpoint 2 how precise do i have to be at each of the checkpoints if your fabric is within 1/8 inch of your target width at each checkpoint you re ok if your fabric is too wide or too narrow by 1/4 inch or more you
